text: <extra_id_0> Bcl-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibits apoptosis induced by a variety of stimuli , including chemotherapy drugs and glucocorticoids .

It is generally accepted that <extra_id_0> Bcl-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> exerts its antiapoptotic effects mainly by dimerizing with proapoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family such as <extra_id_0> Bax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Bad <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: However , the mechanism of the antiapoptotic effects is unclear .

Paclitaxel and other drugs that disturb microtubule dynamics kill cells in a <extra_id_0> Fas <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> Fas ligand <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> FasL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) - dependent manner ; antibody to <extra_id_0> FasL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibits paclitaxel - induced apoptosis .

We have found that <extra_id_0> Bcl-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression leads to the prevention of chemotherapy ( paclitaxel ) - induced expression of <extra_id_0> FasL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and blocks paclitaxel - induced apoptosis .

text: The mechanism of this effect is that <extra_id_0> Bcl-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> prevents the nuclear translocation of NFAT ( nuclear factor of activated T lymphocytes , a transcription factor activated by microtubule damage ) by binding and sequestering calcineurin , a calcium - dependent phosphatase that must dephosphorylate NFAT to move to the nucleus .
Without NFAT nuclear translocation , the <extra_id_0> FasL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene is not transcribed .

text: Thus , it appears that paclitaxel and other drugs that disturb microtubule function kill cells at least in part through the induction of <extra_id_0> FasL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
